overview: UK citizens can work in any European Economic Area country without a work permit - where you can work, your rights, protection for posted workers and National Insurance payments
title: Work in another EU country

table.body:
## Where you can work
As a UK citizen, you have the right to work in any country in the European Economic Area (EEA) without a work permit.

The EEA includes:

- all [countries in the European Union (EU)](http://europa.eu/about-eu/countries/index_en.htm "Countries in the EU: Europa"){:rel="external"}
- Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein

## Your rights
You’ll have the same rights as nationals of the country you’re working in when it comes to:

- working conditions
- pay
- social security (eg benefits)

*[EEA]: European Economic Area
*[EU]: European Union
table.title: Overview

table.body:
If your employer temporarily transfers you from one [European Economic Area (EEA)](overview "Work in another EU country - overview") country to another, you’re a 'posted worker'.

### Protection for posted workers

Your employer must follow some of the employment rules of the country you’ve been posted to. These are the ones relating to:

- maximum work periods and minimum rest periods
- minimum paid annual holidays
- the minimum rates of pay (including overtime)
- health and safety at work
- protection for women who are pregnant or have just given birth
- equal treatment for men and women and other rules to prevent discrimination

$E
**Example:** If the country you’re posted to has a higher minimum wage, your employer must give you that rate or higher.
$E

Your employer is allowed to offer you better employment terms and conditions than the minimum in the country you’ve been posted to.

*[EEA]: European Economic Area
table.title: Posted workers

table.body:
If you go to work in an [European Economic Area (EEA)](overview "Work in another EU country - overview") country, you may have to pay National Insurance contributions for the time you’re abroad.

If you do, [contact HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC)](http://search2.hmrc.gov.uk/kbroker/hmrc/contactus/start.jsp "Contact HMRC"){:rel="external"} who will give you a certificate that lets you do this. Normally, this means you won’t have to pay contributions to the other country’s social security scheme.

*[EEA]: European Economic Area
